title: Non-Deterministic Approximation Fixpoint Theory and Its Application in Disjunctive Logic Programming

sections.approximation fixpoint theory:
We now recall basic notions from approximation fixpoint theory (AFT), as described by Denecker, Marek and TruszczyÅ„skiÂ .
As we have already noted, AFT introduces constructive techniques for approximating the fixpoints of an operator Oğ‘‚O over a lattice L=âŸ¨â„’,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¿â„’L={\langle{\cal L},\leq\rangle}.
This is particularly useful when Oğ‘‚O is non-monotonic (as is often the case in logic programming, default logic and abstract argumentation, and other disciplines
for non-monotonic reasoning in AI), in which case such operators are not guaranteed to even have a fixpoint, or a unique least fixpoint that can be constructively obtained.
AFT generalizes the principles for the construction of fixpoints to the non-monotonic setting, by working with approximations of such operators on a bilattice [ref]4     , constructed on the basis of Lğ¿L. Given a lattice L=âŸ¨â„’,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¿â„’L={\langle{\cal L},\leq\rangle}, a bilattice is the structure L2=âŸ¨â„’2,â‰¤i,â‰¤tâŸ©superscriptğ¿2superscriptâ„’2subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡L^{2}={\langle{\cal L}^{2},\leq_{i},\leq_{t}\rangle}, in which
â„’2=â„’Ã—â„’superscriptâ„’2â„’â„’{\cal L}^{2}={\cal L}\times{\cal L}, and for every x1,y1,x2,y2âˆˆâ„’subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2â„’x_{1},y_{1},x_{2},y_{2}\in{\cal L}, 
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet (x1,y1)â‰¤i(x2,y2)subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2(x_{1},y_{1})\leq_{i}(x_{2},y_{2}) if x1â‰¤x2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2x_{1}\leq x_{2} and y1â‰¥y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}\geq y_{2}, 
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet (x1,y1)â‰¤t(x2,y2)subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2(x_{1},y_{1})\leq_{t}(x_{2},y_{2}) if x1â‰¤x2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2x_{1}\leq x_{2} and y1â‰¤y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}\leq y_{2}.777Recall that we use small letters to denote elements of lattice, capital letters to denote
sets of elements, and capital calligraphic letters to denote sets of sets of elements (TableÂ 1). Bilattices of the form L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} are used for defining operators that approximate operators on Lğ¿L. An approximating operator ğ’ª:â„’2â†’â„’2:ğ’ªâ†’superscriptâ„’2superscriptâ„’2{\cal O}:{\cal L}^{2}\rightarrow{\cal L}^{2} of an operator O:â„’â†’â„’:ğ‘‚â†’â„’â„’O:{\cal L}\rightarrow{\cal L} is an operator that maps every
approximation (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) of an element zğ‘§z to an approximation (xâ€²,yâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²superscriptğ‘¦â€²(x^{\prime},y^{\prime}) of another element Oâ€‹(z)ğ‘‚ğ‘§O(z), thus approximating the behavior of the approximated operator Oğ‘‚O.
Approximation operators may be viewed as combinations of two operators: (ğ’ª(.,.))1({\cal O}(.,.))_{1} and (ğ’ª(.,.))2({\cal O}(.,.))_{2} which calculate, respectively, a lower and
an upper bounds for the value of Oğ‘‚O (where, as usual, (x,y)1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦1(x,y)_{1} respectively (x,y)2subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2(x,y)_{2} represents the first respectively second component of (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)).
To avoid clutter, we will also denote (ğ’ªâ€‹(x,y))1subscriptğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¦1({\cal O}(x,y))_{1} by ğ’ªlâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¥ğ‘¦{\cal O}_{l}(x,y) and (ğ’ªâ€‹(x,y))2subscriptğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¦2({\cal O}(x,y))_{2} by ğ’ªuâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ’ªğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¦{\cal O}_{u}(x,y). Two fundamental requirements on approximating operators are the following: â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonicity: the values of an approximating operator should be more precise as its arguments are more precise, and exactness: exact arguments are mapped
to exact values. These requirements result in the following definition: Let O:â„’â†’â„’:ğ‘‚â†’â„’â„’O:{\cal L}\rightarrow{\cal L} and ğ’ª:â„’2â†’â„’2:ğ’ªâ†’superscriptâ„’2superscriptâ„’2{\cal O}:{\cal L}^{2}\rightarrow{\cal L}^{2}. ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} is â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonic, if when (x1,y1)â‰¤i(x2,y2)subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2(x_{1},y_{1})\leq_{i}(x_{2},y_{2}), also ğ’ªâ€‹(x1,y1)â‰¤iğ’ªâ€‹(x2,y2)subscriptğ‘–ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2{\cal O}(x_{1},y_{1})\leq_{i}{\cal O}(x_{2},y_{2});
ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} is approximating, if it is â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonic and for any xâˆˆâ„’ğ‘¥â„’x\in{\cal L}, ğ’ªlâ€‹(x,x)=ğ’ªuâ€‹(x,x)subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptğ’ªğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¥{\cal O}_{l}(x,x)={\cal O}_{u}(x,x).888In some papers (e.g.,Â ), an approximation operator is defined as a symmetric â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonic operator,
i.e.Â a â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonic operator s.t.Â for every x,yâˆˆâ„’ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â„’x,y\in{\cal L}, ğ’ªâ€‹(x,y)=(ğ’ªlâ€‹(x,y),ğ’ªlâ€‹(y,x))ğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¦ğ‘¥{\cal O}(x,y)=({\cal O}_{l}(x,y),{\cal O}_{l}(y,x)) for some

ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} extends Oğ‘‚O, that is: ğ’ªâ€‹(x,x)=(Oâ€‹(x),Oâ€‹(x))ğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‚ğ‘¥ğ‘‚ğ‘¥{\cal O}(x,x)=(O(x),O(x)) (for every xâˆˆâ„’ğ‘¥â„’x\in{\cal L}). One can define an approximating operator ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} without having to specify which operator Oğ‘‚O
it approximates, and indeed it will often be convenient to study approximating operators without having to refer to the approximated operator.
However, one can easily obtain the operator Oğ‘‚O that ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} approximates by
letting: Oâ€‹(x)=ğ’ªlâ€‹(x,x)ğ‘‚ğ‘¥subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¥ğ‘¥O(x)={\cal O}_{l}(x,x). Another operator that has a central role in AFT and which is used for expressing the semantics of many non-monotonic formalisms is the
stable operator, defined next. For a complete lattice L=âŸ¨â„’,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¿â„’L={\langle{\cal L},\leq\rangle}, let ğ’ª:â„’2â†’â„’2:ğ’ªâ†’superscriptâ„’2superscriptâ„’2{\cal O}:{\cal L}^{2}\rightarrow{\cal L}^{2} be an approximating operator.
We denote: ğ’ªlâ€‹(â‹…,y)=Î»â€‹x.ğ’ªlâ€‹(x,y)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’ªğ‘™â‹…ğ‘¦ğœ†ğ‘¥subscriptğ’ªğ‘™ğ‘¥ğ‘¦{\cal O}_{l}(\cdot,y)=\lambda x.{\cal O}_{l}(x,y) and ğ’ªuâ€‹(x,â‹…)=Î»â€‹y.ğ’ªuâ€‹(x,y)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’ªğ‘¢ğ‘¥â‹…ğœ†ğ‘¦subscriptğ’ªğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¦{\cal O}_{u}(x,\cdot)=\lambda y.{\cal O}_{u}(x,y),

The stable operator for ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} is: S(ğ’ª)(x,y)=(ğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘(ğ’ªl(.,y)),ğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘(ğ’ªu(x,.))S({\cal O})(x,y)=(\mathit{lfp}({\cal O}_{l}(.,y)),\mathit{lfp}({\cal O}_{u}(x,.)). Stable operators capture the idea of minimizing truth, since for any â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-monotonic operator ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} on â„’2superscriptâ„’2{\cal L}^{2},
the fixpoints of the stable operator Sâ€‹(ğ’ª)ğ‘†ğ’ªS({\cal O}) are â‰¤tsubscriptğ‘¡\leq_{t}-minimal fixpoints of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} [22, TheoremÂ 4].
Altogether, the following semantic notions are obtained: Given a complete lattice L=âŸ¨â„’,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¿â„’L={\langle{\cal L},\leq\rangle}, let ğ’ª:â„’2â†’â„’2:ğ’ªâ†’superscriptâ„’2superscriptâ„’2{\cal O}:{\cal L}^{2}\rightarrow{\cal L}^{2} be an approximating operator. Then: (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) is a Kripke-Kleene fixpoint of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} if (x,y)=lfpâ‰¤iâ¡(ğ’ªâ€‹(x,y))ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptlfpsubscriptğ‘–ğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)=\operatorname{lfp}_{\leq_{i}}({\cal O}(x,y)). (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) is a three-valued stable fixpoint of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} if (x,y)=Sâ€‹(ğ’ª)â€‹(x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘†ğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)=S({\cal O})(x,y). (x,x)ğ‘¥ğ‘¥(x,x) is a two-valued stable fixpoints of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} if (x,x)=Sâ€‹(ğ’ª)â€‹(x,x)ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘†ğ’ªğ‘¥ğ‘¥(x,x)=S({\cal O})(x,x). (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y) is the well-founded fixpoint of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O} if it is the â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-minimal (3-valued) stable fixpoint of ğ’ªğ’ª{\cal O}. Denecker, Marek and TruszscyÅ„skiÂ  show that every approximation operator admits a unique â‰¤isubscriptğ‘–\leq_{i}-minimal stable fixpoint.
Pelov, Denecker and BruynoogheÂ  show that for normal logic programs, the fixpoints based on the four-valued immediate consequence operator
for a logic program give rise to the following correspondences: the three-valued stable models coincides with the three-valued semantics as defined by PrzymusinskiÂ ,
the well-founded model coincides with the homonymous semanticsÂ  , and the two-valued stable models coincide with the two-valued
(or total) stable models of a logic program. For a normal logic program ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}, an approximation of the operator ğ¼ğ¶ğ’«subscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ’«\mathit{IC}_{\cal P}Â  can be obtained by first constructing a lower bound operator
